=====5 February=====
=====5 February=====
[[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|Egyptian protesters holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]]
[[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|Egyptian protesters holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]]

During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet.
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet.
â   â
Despite the cold, rainy conditions, anti-government protesters continue to stand their ground at Tahrir Square. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the anti-Mubarak enclave in Tahrir Square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Army-seeks-to-free-Tahrir-Square-for-traffic/articleshow/7433560.cms |title=Army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher=Times of India |date=Feb 5, 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> and asked them to return home so that life could return to normal. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present on the day that during any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb"/> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<!--any idea of where they were from? Arabs, westerners, others?--> have joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing our flowers to the protesters in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb"/> Five hundred protesters also arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb"/> There were also reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb"/>
 
[[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|left|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
[[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|left|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
â
{{External media
+
Despite the cold, rainy conditions, anti-government protesters continue to stand their ground at Tahrir Square. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the anti-Mubarak enclave in Tahrir Square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Army-seeks-to-free-Tahrir-Square-for-traffic/articleshow/7433560.cms |title=Army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher=Times of India |date=Feb 5, 2011 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> and asked them to return home so that life could return to normal. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organised and present on the day that during any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb"/> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners{{Which?|date=February 2011}}<!--any idea of where they were from? Arabs, westerners, others?--> have joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing our flowers to the protesters in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb"/> Five hundred protesters also arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb"/> There were also reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb"/>
â

  â
}}
 
An explosion also occurred on the [[Arab Gas Pipeline]] in the Sinai at a gas pipeline to Israel and Jordan after saboteurs were believed to have responded to a call by Islamist groups to exploit the unrest. Supplies were expected to be cut for a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71408C20110205 |title=UPDATE 1-Jordan gas supplies to be halted a week after blast |publisher=Reuters|date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
An explosion also occurred on the [[Arab Gas Pipeline]] in the Sinai at a gas pipeline to Israel and Jordan after saboteurs were believed to have responded to a call by Islamist groups to exploit the unrest. Supplies were expected to be cut for a week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71408C20110205 |title=UPDATE 1-Jordan gas supplies to be halted a week after blast |publisher=Reuters|date=2009-02-09 |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
